conv_ans.question: Individual
conv_ans.answer:
TIN in Isle of Man is a Tax Reference Number or a National Insurance Number (NINO).
Tax Reference Number is   of 9 characters consisting of 1 letter and six numbers followed by a hyphen and a two digit suffix. Individual Tax Reference Numbers are prefixed with the letter ‘H’. The use of the two digit suffix is in all instances is optional and a Tax Reference Number not including the suffix will be considered acceptable.
National Insurance Number (NINO) is of 9 characters. It consist of two letters, six numbers and a suffix letter A, B, C or D.
Tax Reference No. can be found on Income Tax Return,Assessment Notice.                
NINO can be found on official documents & letters issued by Income Tax Division or Social Security Division of Treasury such as National Insurance Number Card.

_source.question: What are the key features of the Common Reporting Standard
_source.answer: The Common Reporting Standard (CRS) requires financial institutions in a jurisdiction to report to their tax administration the financial accounts held by non-resident individuals and entities or, certain entities controlled by non-resident individuals. Tax administrations are, in turn, expected to share the financial account information with other jurisdictions committed to the CRS through formalized arrangements.

_source.question: What is Wider Approach and how is it beneficial
_source.answer:
Reporting Financial institutions (RFI) are required to put in place necessary procedures and systems to establish the tax residence(s) of all their Account Holders whether they are tax residents of jurisdictions with which RFI jurisdiction has entered into a Competent Authority Agreement (“CAA”) or not, to exchange financial account information. This is known as the “Wider Approach”.

This approach is cost efficient for the industry since Reporting Financial Institutions would not need to repeatedly review the same accounts to re-establish whether the accounts are reportable each time the country enters into a new Competent Authority Agreement (CAA).

_source.question: Financial Assets
_source.answer:
Financial asset includes a security (for example, a share of stock in a corporation; partnership or beneficial ownership interest in a widely held or publicly traded partnership or trust; note, bond, debenture, or other evidence of indebtedness), partnership interest, commodity, swap (for example, interest rate swaps, currency swaps, basis swaps, interest rate caps, interest rate floors, commodity swaps, equity swaps, equity index swaps, and similar agreements), insurance contract or annuity contract, or any interest (including a futures or forward contract or option) in a security, partnership interest, commodity, swap, insurance contract, or annuity contract.
Provided that “financial asset” shall not include a non-debt, direct interest in an immovable property.

_source.question: Who is responsible if the information collected is inaccurate?
_source.answer:
The primary responsibility to provide correct information in the FATCA/CRS declaration is of the customer.
However, Bank has to exercise due diligence at the time of obtaining the FATCA/CRS declaration. If the Relationship Manager / Branch Official finds any difference in the information given on AOF and the FATCA/CRS declaration, eg. Permanent address on AOF is of outside India but in declaration form the customer says ‘No’ to any relation outside of India. In such scenarios, the RM / BO may obtain a valid declaration that establishes accurate information on whether the account holder is a US person or resident for tax purpose outside of India. The RM/BM must conduct reasonable checking to ensure that the new account holder has not provided any contradictory information on the form under communication/permanent address and telephone numbers or within any supporting documentation received under AML/KYC guidelines.

_source.question: Would “execution-only” be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS
_source.answer: An “execution-only” broker that simply executes trading instructions or receives and transmits such instructions to another executing broker will not hold financial assets for the account of others so will not be a Custodial Institution. However, “execution-only” distributors may be financial institutions if they fall within the definition of an investment entity.
variation: Would “execution-only” be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS

_source.question: Would “advisory-only” distributors be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS
_source.answer: “Advisory-only” brokers / distributors may include financial advisors, whose activities do not go beyond the provision of investment advice to their customers and / or acting as an intermediary between the collective investment scheme (CIS), or fund platform and customer. Such distributors will not hold legal title to the assets and therefore are not in the chain of legal ownership of a CIS. As such, they will not be Custodial Institutions. However, “advisory-only” distributors may be financial institutions if they fall within the definition of an investment entity.
variation: Would “advisory-only” distributors be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS

_source.question: I have opened account in other bank, none of them have insisted on FATCA declaration submission why is your bank seeking the same?
_source.answer: It is a regulatory requirement under Section 285BA of the Income-tax Act which mandates every financial Institution to obtain FATCA/CRS declaration from the customer before opening an account and at the time of change of circumstances. The fact that other banks are not insisting for FATCA/CRS declaration cannot be the reason for us to not obtain FATCA/CRS declaration.
variation: I have opened account in other bank, none of them have insisted on FATCA declaration submission why is your bank seeking the same?

_source.question: Can we allow to close the account of a customer who has not submitted FATCA / CRS Declaration?
_source.answer:
For accounts under FATCA freeze, accounts cannot be closed without obtaining the FATCA / CRS declaration.
For accounts frozen only on account of FATCA, Bank induced closure can be done for zero balance accounts as per the existing bank procedures on bank induced closure.

_source.question: Scenarios for obtaining TIN
_source.answer:
TIN has to be obtained in the following scenarios:
1. If the "current residence" or "country of residence for tax purpose" is outside India, then it is mandatory to obtain TIN. If the customer does not have a TIN, then check for the functional equivalent. Functional equiavent can be accepted after taking a specific declaration from the customer that he/she is not issued with any TIN in his/her country of residence for tax purpose.
2. For US Citizens, TIN of US is mandatory even if residence for tax purpose is any country other than India and US. In such scenario, SSN/TIN of US and TIN/Functional Equivalent of the country of tax residence to be obtained. If functional equivalent is being obtained, then specific declaration needs to be taken stating that he/she is not issued with any TIN in his/her country of residence for tax purpose.

_source.question: Depository Institution
_source.answer:
Depository Institution means any entity that accepts deposits in the ordinary course of a banking or similar business.

Entities that fall within this definition include entities regulated in India as a bank, a  Loan Company, a credit society and non-banking financial companies.

A leasing, factoring or invoice discounting business or to an entity that solely lends to business enterprises using loans backed by inventory, accounts receivables, or machinery and equipment will not fall under the category of depository institution. 

Facilitating money transfers by instructing agents to transmit funds (without financing the transactions) is not be considered as the acceptance of a deposit and an entity will not be considered to be engaged in a banking or similar business or a depository institution because of this activity alone.

_source.question: Difference between TIN and functional equivalent
_source.answer:
A tax payer identification number (TIN) is a unique combination of letters or numbers, assigned by a country to an indivuidal or entity and used to identify the identify the individual or entity for the purpose of administering the tax laws of such country. 

Where a person is resident for tax purpose in more than one country or territory outside India, Bank shall maintain the TIN in respect of each such country or territory. 

Country specific TIN can be found by typing "TIN and country".

Many countries do not issue TIN to their taxpayers. However, such countries issue a high integrity number with equivalent level of identification. It is commonly known as functional equivalent. Examples are Social Security Number, National insurance number, Personal identifciation code, resident registration number, etc.

Country specific functional equivalents can be found by typing " functional equivalent and country"

_source.question: In case of dual citizenship, what needs to be submitted by customer
_source.answer:
In case of dual citizenship,
•	If one of the country of citizenship is US, then TIN or SSN of US is to be mandatorily obtained from the customer. 
•	If country of citizenship is other than US and residence for tax purpose is the country of citizenship then, TIN has to be mandatorily obtained of that country.
•	If country of citizenship (other than US) and country of residence for tax purposes is different then, functional equivalent can be obtained of the country of citizenship and TIN to be mandatorily obtained for the country of tax residence.

_source.question: Is the Bank required to collect any documentary proof other than FATCA/CRS declaration?
_source.answer:
There is no requirement to obtain any documentary proof other than FATCA/CRS declaration. It is the responsibility of the customer to provide correct and accurate details. However, the Bank has to exercise due diligence at the time of obtaining the FATCA/CRS declaration. If there is any reason for the branch/RM/operations to believe that the data provided is incorrect, then, necessary documents should be obtained to substantiate the data provided in the FATCA/CRS declaration. 
Examples: 
1. If TIN provided by the customer is not matching with the TIN, syntax provided by OECD. Obtain the tax return copy or any other relevant document which states the Tax number for the customer in the country of his/her tax residence.
2. Permanent address on AOF is of outside India but in declaration form the customer says ‘No’ to any relation outside of India then revised FATCA/CRS declaration or appropriate justification/reasoning to be provided.
3. If the customer is born in US and states that he/she is not a US person then relinquishment of citizenship certificate to be obtained as documentary proof from the customer.

_source.question: What is the definition of a U.S. source payment
_source.answer:
•	U.S. source income is income that arises from sources within the U.S. The source of income is determined based on the type of income. 
•	The source of compensation income is where the services giving rise to the income were performed.
•	The source of certain income, such as dividends and interest, is based on residence of the payer.
•	The source of income from property is based on where the property is used.

_source.question: Investment Entity
_source.answer:
Investment entity means any entity,-
(A) that primarily conducts as a business one or more of the following activities or operations for or on behalf of a customer, namely:-
(i)	trading in money market instruments (cheques, bills, certificates of deposit, derivatives, etc.); foreign exchange; exchange, interest rate and index instruments; transferable securities; or commodity futures trading; or
(ii) 	individual and collective portfolio management; or
(iii)	otherwise investing, administering, or managing financial Assets or money on behalf of other persons; or

(B) the gross income of which is primarily attributable to investing, reinvesting, or trading in financial assets, if the entity is managed by another entity that is a depository institution, a custodial institution, a specified insurance company, or an investment entity described in sub-clause (A) of this clause.

An entity is treated as primarily conducting as a business one or more of the activities described in clause (A) above, or an entity’s gross income is primarily attributable to investing, reinvesting, or trading in financial assets as mentioned in clause (B), if the entity’s gross income attributable to the relevant activities equals or exceeds 50 percent of the entity’s gross income during the shorter of the three-year period ending on 31 March of the year preceding the year in which the determination is made or the period during which the entity has been in existence.

_source.question: Difference between GIIN and LEI
_source.answer:
A Gloabl intermediary Identification Number (GIIN) is a 19-digit alphanumeric identification number. For FATCA reporting Financial Institutions (FIs) will use the GIIN to identify themselves to withholding agents and tax administrations. Once an FI’s FATCA registration is submitted and approved only then is a GIIN issued and only to FIs that are not Limited FFIs, Limited Branches, or U.S. branches of an FFI but to a Participating Foreign Financial Institution (PFFI) or a Registered Deemed-Compliant FFI (RDCFFI).

Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) is a 20-digit alphanumeric code used to identify legal entities. 

The LEI is at a legal entity level and the GIIN is at a lower branch level, a one-to-many relation. A separate GIIN will be issued to a FI to identify each jurisdiction, including the FI’s jurisdiction of residence, in which the FI maintains a branch.

conv_ans.answer:
Excluded/exempt accounts under FATCA/CRS are specified under Explanation to Rule 114F(1) of the Income Tax Rules, 1962
i.	Retirement or pension accounts Explanation (h)(i) to Rule 114F(1) 
ii.	Non-retirement tax-favored accounts Explanation (h)(ii) to Rule 114F(1). 
iii.	Account established under the Senior Citizens Savings Scheme Rules Explanation (h) (iii) to Rule 114F(1). 
iv.	Term Life Insurance contracts satisfying certain conditions Explanation (h)(iv) to Rule 114F(1) 
v.	Accounts held by Estates Explanation (h)(v) to Rule 114F(1). 
vi.	Escrow Accounts established in connection with court judgments; a sale, exchange, or lease of real or personal property; an obligation of a financial institution servicing a loan secured by real property to set aside a portion of a payment solely to facilitate the payment of taxes or insurance related to the real property at a later time; an obligation of a financial institution solely to facilitate the payment of taxes at a later time; Explanation (h)(vi) to Rule 114F(1). 
vii.	Depository accounts (other than US reportable accounts) due to non-returned overpayments in case of credit card and other accounts and satisfying certain conditions Explanation (h)(vii) to Rule 114F(1).

_source.question: Is FATCA applicable to directors who are not beneficial owners or authorised signatory of the entity
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be provided by the entity/non individual account holder. If the entity or the controlling person/beneficial owner is a US person or resident for atx purpose outside India then, controlling person details are required to be provided in the FATCA self-certifciation for non individuals. 

Controlling person is determined by the percentage of holding in the company. If there is no natural person holding more than 25% ownership in the company, then details of senior managing officials who exercise control over the company are required to be obtained in Section 4 of FATCA/CRS self-certification for non individuals.

However, individual FATCA/CRS declaration is not required from directors or authorised signatories.

_source.question: Is FATCA declaration required to be obtained at the time of re-kyc
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained at the time of on-boarding of the customer i.e. account opening and for every change in circumstance.

Currently, for ICICI Bank india, we have not mandated it as a part of re-kyc.

The change in circumstance includes:
1.Change in address to foreign address
2. Update of mobile number to foreign number
3. Addition of signatories in Current account
4. Addition of Power of Attorney (POA)
5. Addition of account holder in Savings account
6. Change in name / title of current account
7. Change in status from Minor to Major if any of the indicia parameter (address, telephone no. citizenship, birth, standing instruction for remittance or power of attorney holder, hold mail or in care of address) is outside India.
8. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
9. Change in citizenship – NRI to RI

For NRI cutsomers, change in circumstances can be under following scenarios:
1. Change in address - country change (Foreign)
2. Updation of mobile number (foreign number)
3. Addition of account holder in Savings account ( Joint Holder addition )
4. Addition of account holder in Savings account - Mandate holder
5. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
6. Change in status from Minor to Major
7. Account Activation

For detailed process, kindly refer e-circular no. 14749

_source.question: Person residing in US and opening an account with the Bank
_source.answer:
Reporting Financial Institutions are required to obtain FATCA/CRS declaration from all account holders. If the US resident has approached the Bank for opening the account, then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained which should include the TIN/SSN of US. 

For existing customers having US indicia i.e. account opened prior to June 30, 2014, if the aggregate account balance or value of the US account holder exceeds USD 50000, then, FATCA/CRS declaration is to be provided by the customer. Necessary communications have been sent to customers to provide the FATCA/CRS declaration. Moreover, if there is any change of circumstance in the account leading to an indicia outside India then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained from that customer before processing the service request.

_source.question: GIIN
_source.answer:
GIIN means a Global Intermediary Identification Number assigned to a Participating Foreign Financial Institutions (PFFI) or Registered Deemed Compliant FFI. A separate GIIN will be issued to the Financial Institutions to identify each jurisdiction, including the FI�s jurisdiction of residence, in which the FI maintains a branch that is not treated as a Limited Branch. _source.question: Applicability of FATCA / CRS
_source.answer:
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015. 

Therefore, it is mandatory for Financial Institutions to obtain FATCA / CRS declaration from all account holders irrespective of their residential status and any indicia outside India, so that due diligence can be carried out to identify the reportable accounts under FATCA/CRS.

_source.question: What is the penalty for non compliance of FATCA/CRS
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS instructions are issued under Section 35A of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 and Section 45 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934. Any contravention thereof or non-compliance shall attract penalties under the Act.

As provided in Rule 114G(9) of the Income Tax Rules, 1962, the statement needs to be furnished to the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation and the said Directorate has been given the responsibility of ensuring the compliance. The penalty provisions provided in the Income-tax Act, 1961, are as under:
(a) Section 271FA of the Income-tax Act, 1961
(i) For failure to furnish the statement of reportable account within the prescribed time limit – Rs. 100 for each day of failure. It is proposed to increase to Rs. 500 for each day of failure.
(ii) For failure to furnish the statement of reportable account after a notice is served on him requiring to file the statement – Rs. 500 for each day of failure. It is proposed to increase the penaly to Rs. 1000 for each day of failure.
(b) Section 271FAA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 provides for levy of a penalty of Rs.50,000 on RFI for furnishing inaccurate information in the statement of reportable account and where
(i) Inaccuracy is due to failure to comply with due diligence requirements or is deliberate on the part of the RFI
(ii) The RFI knows of the inaccuracy at the time of furnishing the statement of reportable account, but does not inform the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation
(iii) The RFI discovers the inaccuracy after the statement of reportable account is furnished and fails to inform and furnish the correct information to the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation within 10 days.

_source.question: Joint account holder is a resident for tax purposes in country outside India or is a Us citizen
_source.answer:

If any joint account holder is a resident for tax purpose in any country outside India then such account will become reportable under FATCA / CRS. Also TIN or functional equivalent of such country of residence for tax purposes is to be mandatorily obtained.
If a joint holder is a US citizen or his country of birth is US then also such account will be reportable under FATCA and SSN or TIN  number of US is to be obtained

_source.question: What should a Reporting FI do with a new account for which the Account Holder had provided a valid self-certification at account opening, but subsequently the self-certification is found to fail the “reasonableness test”.
_source.answer:
Once the Reporting FI has obtained a valid self-certification, it must confirm the reasonableness of the self-certification, based on
•	the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account, 
•	any documentation obtained pursuant to AML/KYC procedures. 

A Reporting FI is considered to have confirmed the reasonableness of a self-certification if it does not know or have reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable. Where the validation of the self-certification takes place after account opening and the self-certification fails the reasonableness test, the Reporting FI is expected to either obtain 
•	a new and valid self-certification or 
•	a reasonable explanation and documentation, as appropriate, supporting the reasonableness of the self-certification within the next 90 days.

_source.question: What if the customer is residing in US but having an account outside US
_source.answer:
Reporting Financial Institutions are required to obtain FATCA/CRs declaration from all account holders. If the US resident has approached the Bank for opening the account, then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained which should include the TIN/SSN of US. 

For existing customers having US indicia i.e. account opened prior to June 30, 2014, if the aggregate account balance or value of the US account holder exceeds USD 50000, then, FATCA/CRS declaration is to be provided by the customer. Moreover, if there is any change of circumstance in the account leading to an indicia outside India then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained from that customer before processing the service request.

_source.question: When is FATCA/CRS declaration required to be obtained
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained at the time of on-boarding of the cutsomer i.e. account opening and for every change in circumstance.

The change in circumstance includes:
1.Change in address to foreign address
2. Update of mobile number to foreign number
3. Addition of signatories in Current account
4. Addition of Power of Attorney (POA)
5. Addition of account holder in Savings account
6. Change in name / title of current account
7. Change in status from Minor to Major if any of the indicia parameter (address, telephone no. citizenship, birth, standing instruction for remittance or power of attorney holder, hold mail or in care of address) is outside India.
8. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
9. Change in citizenship – NRI to RI

For NRI cutsomers, change in circumstances can be under following scenarios:
1. Change in address - country change (Foreign)
2. Updation of mobile number (foreign number)
3. Addition of account holder in Savings account ( Joint Holder addition )
4. Addition of account holder in Savings account - Mandate holder
5. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
6. Change in status from Minor to Major
7. Account Activation

For detailed process, kindly refer e-circular no. 14749

_source.question: Difference between GIIN and TIN
_source.answer:
GIIN means a Global Intermediary Identification Number assigned to a PFFI or Registered Deemed Compliant FFI. A separate GIIN will be issued to the FI to identify each jurisdiction, including the FI's jurisdiction of residence, in which the FI maintains a branch that is not treated as a Limited Branch. GIIN is assigned to each financial institutions for purposes of identifying their registration with the IRS under FATCA.

A Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) is an identifying number used for tax purposes. TINs are different in each country.

_source.question: Threshold for the purpose of FATCA/CRS reporting
_source.answer:

With respect of CRS, all accounts irrespective of the balance in customers account are required to be reported.

_source.question: How do we know if a jurisdiction issue TIN
_source.answer:
Information with respect to committed jurisdictions’ TINs and tax residency rules are available at the OECD AEOI Portal to help both taxpayers and financial institutions comply with their obligations under the CRS. Please refer find the below link: 
http://www.oecd.org/tax/automatic-exchange/crs-implementation-and-assistance/tax-identification-numbers/

Account Holders that are unsure of their tax residency can either seek advice from the tax administration which they believe they could be resident in or from a tax practitioner.

_source.answer:
TIN in Argentina is Clave Única de or C.U.I.T (Single Tax Identifciation Code). It is a 11 digit tax identity number.
Those who are not issued CUIT are issued with CDI (Identification Code). It is a numeric Identification code issued to entities for those who are not required to have CUIT as there is no tax reason.  
CUIL ( Unified Labour identification Code)  is also Issued automatically for social security benefit purpose.
CUIT can be found on AFIP website.

_source.question: Whta is the penalty for non compliance of FATCA/CRS
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS instructions are issued under Section 35A of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 and Section 45 of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934. Any contravention thereof or non-compliance shall attract penalties under the Act.

As provided in Rule 114G(9) of the Income Tax Rules, 1962, the statement needs to be furnished to the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation and the said Directorate has been given the responsibility of ensuring the compliance. The penalty provisions provided in the Income-tax Act, 1961, are as under:
(a) Section 271FA of the Income-tax Act, 1961
(i) For failure to furnish the statement of reportable account within the prescribed time limit – Rs. 100 for each day of failure. It is proposed to increase to Rs. 500 for each day of failure.
(ii) For failure to furnish the statement of reportable account after a notice is served on him requiring to file the statement – Rs. 500 for each day of failure. It is proposed to increase the penaly to Rs. 1000 for each day of failure.
(b) Section 271FAA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 provides for levy of a penalty of Rs.50,000 on RFI for furnishing inaccurate information in the statement of reportable account and where
(i) Inaccuracy is due to failure to comply with due diligence requirements or is deliberate on the part of the RFI
(ii) The RFI knows of the inaccuracy at the time of furnishing the statement of reportable account, but does not inform the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation
(iii) The RFI discovers the inaccuracy after the statement of reportable account is furnished and fails to inform and furnish the correct information to the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation within 10 days.

_source.question: When is FATCA/CRS declaration required to be obtained
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained at the time of on-boarding of the cutsomer i.e. account opening and for every change in circumstance.

The change in circumstance includes:
1.Change in address to foreign address
2. Update of mobile number to foreign number
3. Addition of signatories in Current account
4. Addition of Power of Attorney (POA)
5. Addition of account holder in Savings account
6. Change in name / title of current account
7. Change in status from Minor to Major if any of the indicia parameter (address, telephone no. citizenship, birth, standing instruction for remittance or power of attorney holder, hold mail or in care of address) is outside India.
8. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
9. Change in citizenship – NRI to RI

For NRI cutsomers, change in circumstances can be under following scenarios:
1. Change in address - country change (Foreign)
2. Updation of mobile number (foreign number)
3. Addition of account holder in Savings account ( Joint Holder addition )
4. Addition of account holder in Savings account - Mandate holder
5. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
6. Change in status from Minor to Major
7. Account Activation

For detailed process, kindly refer e-circular no. 14749
variation: When is FATCA/CRS declaration required to be obtained
When is FATCA declaration required to be obtained
When is CRS declaration required to be obtained

_source.question: What are the various Indicia’s to determine residence outside India
_source.answer:
•	Place of birth outside India
•	Residence address outside India
•	Citizenship outside India
•	Country of residence for tax purposes outside India
•	Telephone number outside India
•	Power of attorney or signatory authority granted to a person with an address in a country or territory outside India
•	A “hold mail” instruction or “in-care-of” address in a country or territory outside India

_source.question: What is pre-existing low value individual accounts under FATCA
_source.answer:
Individual Accounts existing as on June 30, 2014 and having a balance more than USD 50000 but less than 1,000,000 as on June 30, 2014 are low value accounts under FATCA. 
The threshold to be considered at UCIC level i.e. at customer level.

_source.question: When is enhanced due diligence required to be carried out
_source.answer: Enhanced due diligence for accounts which were less than USD 1 Mn as on June 30, 2014 and Dec 31, 2015 but have exceeded USD 1 Mn as at end of each calendar year is required to be completed by end of December in the year in which it is identified. This activity has to be carried out annually.

_source.question: what is PFFI
_source.answer:
An Foreign Financial institution (FFI) that: 
(1) is registering to agree to enter into an FFI Agreement, 
(2) is treated as a Reporting FI under a Model 2 IGA and that is certifying that it will comply with the terms of an FFI Agreement, as modified by the terms of the applicable Model 2 IGA, or 
(3) is a foreign branch of a USFI that has in effect a QI Agreement and that is also agreeing to the terms of an FFI Agreement, unless such branch is treated as a Reporting FI under a Model 1 IGA.

_source.question: Depository Account
_source.answer:
Depository Account includes any commercial, checking, savings, time, or thrift account, or an account that is evidenced by a certificate of deposit, thrift certificate, investment certificate, certificate of indebtedness, or other similar instrument maintained by a financial institution in the ordinary course of a banking or similar business and also an amount held by an insurance company pursuant to a guaranteed investment contract or similar agreement to pay or credit interest thereon.

A Depository Account includes an amount that an insurance company holds under an agreement to pay or credit interest thereon

A Depository Account does not include an advance premium or premium deposit received by an insurance company provided the prepayment or deposit relates to an Insurance Contract for which the premium is payable annually and the amount of the prepayment or deposit does not exceed the annual premium for the contract. Such amounts are also excluded from Cash Value for purposes of determining whether a contract is a Cash Value Insurance Contract.

_source.question: What are the checks or verification requirements to be carried out or conducted in the FATCA / CRS declaration?
_source.answer:
Some checks required to be carried out while obtaining FATCA / CRS declaration are:
1.	Ensure that FATCA / CRS declaration is completely filled in by the customer.
2.	Ensure that appropriate TIN value as per the format prescribed is provided by the customer.
3.	Customer declaration in Part III of the FATCA / CRS declaration is to be signed mandatorily.
4.	Self-Certification is signed only when required.
5.	Controlling person details for entities which are Passive NFE, Specified US Persons or Owner documented FFI are mandatorily obtained.
6.	Where nationality is US and country is any country other than US then TIN value should have two TIN values one of US (9 digits) and one of the country as per the format prescribed by OECD.
7.	If Country of birth is US then TIN value of US is also required else Self-certification is to be signed.
8.	If Nationality is US then TIN of US should also be obtained
9.	Nationality is US then US TIN should be of 9 digits.
10.	Details provided in FATCA / CRS declaration is not in contradiction with the details provided in AOF.
variation: What are the checks or verification requirements to be carried out or conducted in the FATCA / CRS declaration?

_source.question: What are the obligations under CRS of a Financial Institution to establish the tax residency of its customers in relation to the New Account procedures
_source.answer: A Financial Institution is not required to provide customers with tax advice or to perform a legal analysis to determine the reasonableness of self-certification. Instead, as provided in the Standard, for New Accounts the Financial Institution may rely on a self-certification made by the customer unless it knows or has reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable, (the “reasonableness” test), which will be based on the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account, including any documentation obtained pursuant to AML/KYC procedures
variation: What are the obligations under CRS of a Financial Institution to establish the tax residency of its customers in relation to the New Account procedures

_source.question: What is pre-existing low value individual accounts under FATCA
_source.answer:
Individual Accounts existing as on June 30, 2014 and having a balance more than USD 50000 but less than 1,000,000 as on June 30, 2014 are low value accounts under FATCA. 
The threshold to be considered at UCIC level i.e. at customer level.

_source.question: When is enhanced due diligence required to be carried out
_source.answer: Enhanced due diligence for accounts which were less than USD 1 Mn as on June 30, 2014 and Dec 31, 2015 but have exceeded USD 1 Mn as at end of each calendar year is required to be completed by end of December in the year in which it is identified. This activity has to be carried out annually.

_source.question: Custodial Institution
_source.answer:
Custodial institution means any entity that holds, as a substantial portion of its business, financial assets for the account of others and where its income attributable to the holding of financial assets and related financial services equals or exceeds twenty per cent of its gross income during the three financial years preceding the year in which determination is made or the period during which the entity has been in existence, whichever is less.

Investment dealers, brokerages, trust companies, and other entities would be expected to be custodial institutions.

_source.question: Related entity
_source.answer:
An entity is a related entity of another entity if either entity controls the other entity, or the two entities are under common control. 

Control includes direct or indirect ownership of more than fifty per cent of the votes and value in an entity.

_source.question: What is Withholding Certificate
_source.answer:
The term withholding certificate means a Form W-8, Form W-9, or any other certificate that under the Code or regulations certifies or establishes the chapter 4 status of a payee or beneficial owner under FATCA. 

The various withholding certificates are:
1. W8BEN (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding)(Individuals)
2. W8BENE (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding) (Entities)
3. W8ECI (Certificate of Foreign Person's Claim That Income Is Effectively Connected With the Conduct of a Trade or Business in the United States)
4. W8EXP (Certificate of Foreign Government or Other Foreign Organization for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
5. W8IMY (Certificate of Foreign Intermediary, Foreign Flow-Through Entity, or Certain U.S. Branches for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
6. W9 (Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification from US person)
variation: What is Withholding Certificate
Withholding Certificate

_source.question: Financial Account
_source.answer:
Financial Account means an account (other than an excluded account) maintained by a financial institution, and includes- 
i.	a depository account, 
ii.	a custodial account,
iii.	in the case of an investment entity, any equity or debt interest in the financial institution,
iv.	in the case of a financial institution not described in sub-clause (iii), any equity or debt interest in the financial institution, if the class of interests was established with a purpose of avoiding reporting in accordance with rule 114G and, in case of a U.S. reportable account, if the value of the debt or equity interest is determined, directly or indirectly, primarily by reference to assets that give rise to U.S. source withholdable payments; and
v.	any cash value Insurance contract and any annuity contract issued or maintained by a financial institution, other than a noninvestment-linked, non-transferable immediate life annuity that is issued to an individual and monetizes a pension or disability benefit provided under an account that is an excluded account.

Financial account will not include any equity or debt interest in an entity that is an investment entity solely because it 
a.	renders investment advice to, and acts on behalf of, or 
b.	manages portfolios for, and acts on behalf of, a customer for the purpose of investing, managing, or administering financial assets deposited in the name of the customer with a financial institution that is not a non-participating financial institution other than such entity;
variation: Financial Account

conv_ans.question: Individual
conv_ans.answer:
TIN in Isle of Man is a Tax Reference Number or a National Insurance Number (NINO).
Tax Reference Number is   of 9 characters consisting of 1 letter and six numbers followed by a hyphen and a two digit suffix. Individual Tax Reference Numbers are prefixed with the letter ‘H’. The use of the two digit suffix is in all instances is optional and a Tax Reference Number not including the suffix will be considered acceptable.
National Insurance Number (NINO) is of 9 characters. It consist of two letters, six numbers and a suffix letter A, B, C or D.
Tax Reference No. can be found on Income Tax Return,Assessment Notice.                
NINO can be found on official documents & letters issued by Income Tax Division or Social Security Division of Treasury such as National Insurance Number Card.

_source.question: Closure of account under FATCA
_source.answer:
As per the IGA entered into between US and India, accounts opened between July 1, 2014 to August 31, 2015 were required to be closed. However, CBDT issued a press release to all financial institutions in India on April 11, 2017, that instead of closure of accounts, financial institutions shall not permit any customer induced transactions w.e.f May 1, 2017 in the accounts opened from July 1, 2014 to August 31, 2015 for which FATCA declaration could not be obtained. Hence, all financial institutions in India were required to mark a total freeze on the accounts.
However, there is no such requirement to close or freeze the account under CRS.

As india has entered into a Model 1 IGA with US government, the financial isntitutions in India will be guided by the rules/clarifications/guidance issued by CBDT from time to time.

_source.question: TIN of Belize
_source.answer:
TIN in Belize is of 8 digits.It consists of 6 digit TIN + 2 digit code for tax type. It consists of numbers only.
There is a coding of tax types which is reflected in two additional digits that are added to the unique TIN. 10 (for personal income tax), 13 (for business tax) and 66 (for general sales tax).
It can be found on Top right corner of Tax Return forms. 
 TIN are issued only if there is a tax obligation.

conv_ans.question: Individual
conv_ans.answer:
TIN in Estonia is a Personal Identification code (Isikukood).It is of 11 digits
The format is GYYMMDDSSSC, where G shows sex and century of birth (odd number male, even number female, 1-2 19th century, 3-4 20th century, 5-6 21st century), YY is the year of birth, MM is the month of birth and DD is the date of birth.
It can be found on passports, driving licence, Estonian citizen ID cards.

_source.question: When is a trust that is a Financial Institution considered to be resident in a Participating Jurisdiction?
_source.answer: In general, a Financial Institution is resident in a Participating Jurisdiction if it is a resident for tax purposes in the jurisdiction. In the case of a trust that is a Financial Institution (irrespective of whether it is resident for tax purposes in a Participating Jurisdiction), the trust is considered to be a resident in a Participating Jurisdiction if one or more of its trustees are tax resident in such Participating Jurisdiction except if the trust reports all the information required to be reported to another Participating Jurisdiction because it is resident for tax purposes in such other Participating Jurisdiction.
variation: When is a trust that is a Financial Institution considered to be resident in a Participating Jurisdiction?
When is trust considered to be resident in a Participating Jurisdiction

_source.question: Does the Standard require a Reporting Financial Institution to retain a paper copy of the Documentary Evidence collected as part of its due diligence procedures?
_source.answer: No. A Reporting Financial Institution is not required to retain a paper copy of the Documentary Evidence, but may do so. A Reporting Financial institution may retain an original, certified copy, or photocopy of the Documentary Evidence or, instead, a notation of the type of documentation reviewed, the date the documentation was reviewed, and the document’s identification number (if any) (for example, a passport number).

_source.question: What are the key features of the Common Reporting Standard
_source.answer: The Common Reporting Standard (CRS) requires financial institutions in a jurisdiction to report to their tax administration the financial accounts held by non-resident individuals and entities or, certain entities controlled by non-resident individuals. Tax administrations are, in turn, expected to share the financial account information with other jurisdictions committed to the CRS through formalized arrangements.

_source.question: MCAA
_source.answer: MCAA is Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement.  The Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (the MCAA) is a multilateral framework agreement that provides a standardised and efficient mechanism to facilitate the automatic exchange of information in accordance with the Standard for Automatic Exchange of Financial Information in Tax Matters. It is used in the context of CRS.
variation: MCAA

_source.question: What are Reportable Accounts under CRS
_source.answer:
Accounts held by the following are reportable accounts under CRS
•	Person resident for tax purpose outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Passive NFE with controlling persons outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Entity resident for tax purpose outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Other Reportable Person

_source.question: What is meant by ‘reasonableness test’?
_source.answer:
A Reporting FI is considered to have confirmed the “reasonableness” of a self-certification if it does not know or have reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable in the course of account opening procedures and upon review of the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account (including any documentation collected and maintained pursuant to AML/KYC Procedures). 

Reporting FI has reason to know that a self-certification or Documentary Evidence is unreliable or incorrect if its knowledge of relevant facts or statements contained in the self-certification or other documentation, including the knowledge of the relevant relationship managers, if any, is such that a reasonably prudent person in the position of the FI would question the claim being made. 

A Reporting FI also has reason to know that a self-certification or Documentary Evidence is unreliable or incorrect if there is information in the documentation or in the Reporting FI’s account files that conflicts with the person’s claim regarding its status.

_source.question: What is functional equivalent
_source.answer:
Many countries do not issue TIN to their tax payers. However, such countries issue some high integrity number with an equivalent level of identification (a functional equivalent). Examples of scuh numbers are:
1. Social Security Number
2. National Insurance Number
3. Citizen or Personal Identifciation Code or number
4. Resident registration Number

For entities, a business/ company registration code/number may be used in case where no TIN has been issued to teh entity. These numbers are functional equiavlent of TIN.

Country specific functional equivalents can be found by typing " functional equivalent and country name".

_source.question: Is there a requirement of freezing the account under FATCA/CRS
_source.answer:
As per the notification issued by CBDT dated April 11, 2017 accounts opened between July 1, 2014 to August 31, 2015 have been frozen under FATCA where FATCA/CRS declaration was not provided by the customer till April 30, 2017.

Under CRS, there is no requirement of freezing the accounts.

_source.question: What is SSN
_source.answer: In the United States, a Social Security number (SSN) is a nine-digit number issued to U.S. citizens, permanent residents, and temporary (working) residents. The number is issued to an individual by the Social Security Administration (SSA). Its primary purpose is to track individuals for Social Security purposes. You need a Social Security number to work, collect Social Security benefits, and receive some other government services.

_source.question: What is Change of Circumstance
_source.answer:
Change of Circumstance includes any change that results in the addition of information relevant to a person’s status or otherwise conflicts with such person’s status. In addition, a change of circumstances includes any change or addition of information to the account holder’s account (including the addition, substitution, or other change of an account holder) or any change or addition of information to any account associated with such account (applying the account aggregation rules) if such change or addition of information affects the status of the account holder.

If there is a change in circumstance with respect to an account that causes the Reporting Financial institution to know or have reasons to know that the self-certification or any other documentation associated with an account is incorrect or unreliable, the Reporting FI must re-determine the status of the account in accordance with the applicable due diligence procedures immediately.

_source.question: What is Active NFFE
_source.answer:
Active NFFE is a non-financial entity means any non-financial entity which meets any of the following criteria, namely:-
•	Less than 50 percent of the NFFE’s gross income for the preceding calendar year or other appropriate reporting period is passive income and less than 50 percent of the assets held by the NFFE during the preceding calendar year or other appropriate reporting period are assets that produce or are held for the production of passive income
•	The stock of NFFE or its affiliate is regularly traded on established securities market
•	The NFFE is a government (other than the U.S. government), a political subdivision of such government (which, for the avoidance of doubt, includes a state, province, county, or municipality), or a public body performing a function of such government or a political subdivision thereof, a government of a U.S. Territory, an international organization, a non-U.S. central bank of issue, or an entity wholly owned by one or more of the foregoing
•	The NFFE is organized in a U.S. Territory and all of the owners of the payee are bona fide residents of that U.S. Territory
•	The NFFE was not a FI in the past five years, and is in the process of liquidating its assets or is reorganizing with the intent to continue or recommence operations in a business other than that of a FI 
•	The NFFE meets all the requirements applicable to certain not-for-profit organizations
o	It is established and operated in its jurisdiction of residence exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, artistic, cultural, athletic, educational purposes or for promotion of social welfare
o	It is exempt from income tax in its jurisdiction of residence 
o	It has no shareholders or members who have a proprietary or beneficial interest in its income or assets
o	Applicable laws of the NFFE’s jurisdiction of residence  do not permit any income or assets of the NFFE to be distributed to, or applied for the benefit of, a private person or non-charitable Entity
o	Applicable laws of the NFFE’s jurisdiction of residence require that, upon liquidation or dissolution, all of its assets be distributed to a governmental entity or other non-profit organization
variation: What is Active NFFE

_source.question: I am not a citizen of US nor was I born there why are u seeking FATCA declaration from me?
_source.answer:
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015. 

Therefore, it is mandatory for Financial Institutions to obtain FATCA / CRS declaration even if there is no US indicia so that due diligence can be carried out and only reportable accounts can be reported to CBDT.
variation: I am not a citizen of US nor was I born there why are u seeking FATCA declaration from me?
Is FATCA/ CRS applicable to a person with no US connection
Is the customer required to provide FATCA declaration when there is no US indicia

_source.question: If a person of Indian origin residing in US permanently moves back to India, is he a US person under FATCA
_source.answer:
US person is a person resident or citizen of US. If the person has aquired citizenship during his/her stay in US then, he/she will be termed as US person.
If the person has moved permanently to India without aquiring citizenship of US and is not a resident for tax purpose of US then, he/she will not be a US person.

However, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be mandatorily obtained at the time of account opening or change of circumstance.
variation: If a person of Indian origin residing in US permanently moves back to India, is he a US person under FATCA

conv_ans.answer:
TIN in UK is Unique Taxpayer reference(UTR) or National Insurance Number. UTR is of 10 numerals. NINO is of 9 characters. 
National Insurance Number (NINO) is issued to young people living in UK when they approach the age of 16.
NINO  consists of two letters, six numbers and a suffix letter A, B, C or D. TINs are not issued to all UK resident taxpayers or all nationals. This includes those under 16 years of age, those who do not have a right to work in the UK as well as those with no UK tax or National Insurance Contributions Liability.
UTR can be found on front page of Tax Return. NINO can be found on Coding Notices by HM Revenue & Customs, National Insurance Card, Letters issued by Dept. of Work & Pensions(DWP), employee's pay slip.

_source.question: What is Withholding Certificate
_source.answer:
The term withholding certificate means a Form W-8, Form W-9, or any other certificate that under the Code or regulations certifies or establishes the chapter 4 status of a payee or beneficial owner under FATCA. 

The various withholding certificates are:
1. W8BEN (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding)(Individuals)
2. W8BENE (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding) (Entities)
3. W8ECI (Certificate of Foreign Person's Claim That Income Is Effectively Connected With the Conduct of a Trade or Business in the United States)
4. W8EXP (Certificate of Foreign Government or Other Foreign Organization for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
5. W8IMY (Certificate of Foreign Intermediary, Foreign Flow-Through Entity, or Certain U.S. Branches for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
6. W9 (Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification from US person)

_source.question: What is Wider Approach and how is it beneficial
_source.answer:
Reporting Financial institutions (RFI) are required to put in place necessary procedures and systems to establish the tax residence(s) of all their Account Holders whether they are tax residents of jurisdictions with which RFI jurisdiction has entered into a Competent Authority Agreement (“CAA”) or not, to exchange financial account information. This is known as the “Wider Approach”.

This approach is cost efficient for the industry since Reporting Financial Institutions would not need to repeatedly review the same accounts to re-establish whether the accounts are reportable each time the country enters into a new Competent Authority Agreement (CAA).
variation: What is Wider Approach and how is it beneficial

_source.question: What should the Reporting FI do if it is unable to obtain a new and valid self-certification with respect to existing accounts
_source.answer: The Reporting FI is not required to close the account, but will have to report the Account Holder to the respective regulators based on the residence status provided in the original self-certification and any other jurisdiction(s) in which the Reporting FI has indications that the Account Holder is resident in. Reporting FIs are expected to continue to use reasonable efforts to obtain a valid self-certification from the Account Holder. Such efforts must be made at least once a year until (i) a new and valid self-certification or (ii) a reasonable explanation and documentation is obtained.

_source.answer: No. The CRS status of intermediate Entities in the ownership chain is irrelevant for these purposes. It is necessary to obtain the details of controlling persons irrespective of whether there is a Reporting Financial institution in the chain of ownership.

_source.question: Depository Account
_source.answer:
Depository Account includes any commercial, checking, savings, time, or thrift account, or an account that is evidenced by a certificate of deposit, thrift certificate, investment certificate, certificate of indebtedness, or other similar instrument maintained by a financial institution in the ordinary course of a banking or similar business and also an amount held by an insurance company pursuant to a guaranteed investment contract or similar agreement to pay or credit interest thereon.

A Depository Account includes an amount that an insurance company holds under an agreement to pay or credit interest thereon

A Depository Account does not include an advance premium or premium deposit received by an insurance company provided the prepayment or deposit relates to an Insurance Contract for which the premium is payable annually and the amount of the prepayment or deposit does not exceed the annual premium for the contract. Such amounts are also excluded from Cash Value for purposes of determining whether a contract is a Cash Value Insurance Contract.

_source.question: Who is responsible if the information collected is inaccurate?
_source.answer:
The primary responsibility to provide correct information in the FATCA/CRS declaration is of the customer.
However, Bank has to exercise due diligence at the time of obtaining the FATCA/CRS declaration. If the Relationship Manager / Branch Official finds any difference in the information given on AOF and the FATCA/CRS declaration, eg. Permanent address on AOF is of outside India but in declaration form the customer says ‘No’ to any relation outside of India. In such scenarios, the RM / BO may obtain a valid declaration that establishes accurate information on whether the account holder is a US person or resident for tax purpose outside of India. The RM/BM must conduct reasonable checking to ensure that the new account holder has not provided any contradictory information on the form under communication/permanent address and telephone numbers or within any supporting documentation received under AML/KYC guidelines.

_source.question: What is to be done in cases where the customer’s Country of Birth is US & is a Tax resident of a country outside India.
_source.answer:
Following steps are to be followed:
•	Check with customer for TIN of US.
•	If the customer does not provide the TIN of US, then ask for relinquishment of citizenship certificate.
•	If the customer does not have such certificate, then ask for the reason for not having the relinquishment certificate.
•	Ask the customer to sign the self-certification section.of the FATCA/CRS declaration
•	Additionally, if the cutsomer iss resident for tax purpose in a country other than India and US, then, ask the customer to provide the TIN for his/her country of residence for tax purpose.

_source.question: What is pre-existing high value individual accounts under FATCA
_source.answer:
Individual Accounts existing as on June 30, 2014 and having a balance more than USD 1,000,000 as on June 30, 2014 are high value accounts under FATCA. 
The threshold of USD 1,000,000 to be considered at UCIC level i.e. at customer level.
variation: What is pre-existing high value individual accounts under FATCA

_source.question: What is pre-existing high value individual accounts under CRS
_source.answer: Individual Accounts existing as on December 31, 2015 and having a balance more than USD 1,000,000 as on December 31, 2015 are high value accounts under CRS. The threshold of USD 1,000,000 to be considered at UCIC level i.e. at customer level.

_source.question: What is a recalcitrant account holder?
_source.answer:
Generally, a recalcitrant account holder is any account holder that 
(1) fails to comply with reasonable requests for information necessary to determine if the account is a United States account; 
(2) fails to provide the name, address, and TIN of each “specified United States person” and each substantial United States owner of a United States owned foreign entity; or 
(3) fails to provide a waiver of any foreign law that would prevent a foreign financial institution from reporting information required under FATCA

_source.question: Would “execution-only” be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS
_source.answer: An “execution-only” broker that simply executes trading instructions or receives and transmits such instructions to another executing broker will not hold financial assets for the account of others so will not be a Custodial Institution. However, “execution-only” distributors may be financial institutions if they fall within the definition of an investment entity.
variation: Would “execution-only” be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS

_source.question: Would “advisory-only” distributors be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS
_source.answer: “Advisory-only” brokers / distributors may include financial advisors, whose activities do not go beyond the provision of investment advice to their customers and / or acting as an intermediary between the collective investment scheme (CIS), or fund platform and customer. Such distributors will not hold legal title to the assets and therefore are not in the chain of legal ownership of a CIS. As such, they will not be Custodial Institutions. However, “advisory-only” distributors may be financial institutions if they fall within the definition of an investment entity.
variation: Would “advisory-only” distributors be considered as Custodial Institutions under the CRS

_source.question: I have opened account in other bank, none of them have insisted on FATCA declaration submission why is your bank seeking the same?
_source.answer: It is a regulatory requirement under Section 285BA of the Income-tax Act which mandates every financial Institution to obtain FATCA/CRS declaration from the customer before opening an account and at the time of change of circumstances. The fact that other banks are not insisting for FATCA/CRS declaration cannot be the reason for us to not obtain FATCA/CRS declaration.
variation: I have opened account in other bank, none of them have insisted on FATCA declaration submission why is your bank seeking the same?

_source.question: Can we allow to close the account of a customer who has not submitted FATCA / CRS Declaration?
_source.answer:
For accounts under FATCA freeze, accounts cannot be closed without obtaining the FATCA / CRS declaration.
For accounts frozen only on account of FATCA, Bank induced closure can be done for zero balance accounts as per the existing bank procedures on bank induced closure.

_source.question: I am US citizen with US passport, have a PAN and AADHHAR too, do I still need to give a FATCA certification. Why do I fill in the FATCA declaration?
_source.answer:
Yes, FATCA / CRS declaration is to be obtained for US citizens along with the SSN or TIN number of US.
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 form part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015.
variation: I am US citizen with US passport, have a PAN and AADHHAR too, do I still need to give a FATCA certification. Why do I fill in the FATCA declaration?

_source.question: What are the checks or verification requirements to be carried out or conducted in the FATCA / CRS declaration?
_source.answer:
Some checks required to be carried out while obtaining FATCA / CRS declaration are:
1.	Ensure that FATCA / CRS declaration is completely filled in by the customer.
2.	Ensure that appropriate TIN value as per the format prescribed is provided by the customer.
3.	Customer declaration in Part III of the FATCA / CRS declaration is to be signed mandatorily.
4.	Self-Certification is signed only when required.
5.	Controlling person details for entities which are Passive NFE, Specified US Persons or Owner documented FFI are mandatorily obtained.
6.	Where nationality is US and country is any country other than US then TIN value should have two TIN values one of US (9 digits) and one of the country as per the format prescribed by OECD.
7.	If Country of birth is US then TIN value of US is also required else Self-certification is to be signed.
8.	If Nationality is US then TIN of US should also be obtained
9.	Nationality is US then US TIN should be of 9 digits.
10.	Details provided in FATCA / CRS declaration is not in contradiction with the details provided in AOF.
variation: What are the checks or verification requirements to be carried out or conducted in the FATCA / CRS declaration?

_source.question: What are the obligations under CRS of a Financial Institution to establish the tax residency of its customers in relation to the New Account procedures
_source.answer: A Financial Institution is not required to provide customers with tax advice or to perform a legal analysis to determine the reasonableness of self-certification. Instead, as provided in the Standard, for New Accounts the Financial Institution may rely on a self-certification made by the customer unless it knows or has reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable, (the “reasonableness” test), which will be based on the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account, including any documentation obtained pursuant to AML/KYC procedures

_source.question: Are rollovers considered as new accounts
_source.answer: The treatment of rollovers is the same under CRS and FATCA. _source.question: Scenarios for obtaining TIN
_source.answer:
TIN has to be obtained in the following scenarios:
1. If the "current residence" or "country of residence for tax purpose" is outside India, then it is mandatory to obtain TIN. If the customer does not have a TIN, then check for the functional equivalent. Functional equiavent can be accepted after taking a specific declaration from the customer that he/she is not issued with any TIN in his/her country of residence for tax purpose.
2. For US Citizens, TIN of US is mandatory even if residence for tax purpose is any country other than India and US. In such scenario, SSN/TIN of US and TIN/Functional Equivalent of the country of tax residence to be obtained. If functional equivalent is being obtained, then specific declaration needs to be taken stating that he/she is not issued with any TIN in his/her country of residence for tax purpose.

_source.question: Reporting due date for FATCA/CRS in India
_source.answer:
In India, FATCA and CRS reporting is to be done to Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) on an annual basis.

All information for the relevant reporting year is to be submitted to CBDT through Form 61B for every calendar year by 31st day of May of the year following the end of the reporting year. For example, a Reporting FI is required to submit information for Reporting Year 2017 to CBDT by 31st May 2018.

_source.question: Custodial Institution
_source.answer:
Custodial institution means any entity that holds, as a substantial portion of its business, financial assets for the account of others and where its income attributable to the holding of financial assets and related financial services equals or exceeds twenty per cent of its gross income during the three financial years preceding the year in which determination is made or the period during which the entity has been in existence, whichever is less.

Investment dealers, brokerages, trust companies, and other entities would be expected to be custodial institutions.

_source.question: What is meant by ‘reasonableness test’?
_source.answer:
A Reporting FI is considered to have confirmed the “reasonableness” of a self-certification if it does not know or have reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable in the course of account opening procedures and upon review of the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account (including any documentation collected and maintained pursuant to AML/KYC Procedures). 

Reporting FI has reason to know that a self-certification or Documentary Evidence is unreliable or incorrect if its knowledge of relevant facts or statements contained in the self-certification or other documentation, including the knowledge of the relevant relationship managers, if any, is such that a reasonably prudent person in the position of the FI would question the claim being made. 

A Reporting FI also has reason to know that a self-certification or Documentary Evidence is unreliable or incorrect if there is information in the documentation or in the Reporting FI’s account files that conflicts with the person’s claim regarding its status.
variation: What is meant by ‘reasonableness test’?

_source.question: What is functional equivalent
_source.answer:
Many countries do not issue TIN to their tax payers. However, such countries issue some high integrity number with an equivalent level of identification (a functional equivalent). Examples of scuh numbers are:
1. Social Security Number
2. National Insurance Number
3. Citizen or Personal Identifciation Code or number
4. Resident registration Number

For entities, a business/ company registration code/number may be used in case where no TIN has been issued to teh entity. These numbers are functional equiavlent of TIN.

Country specific functional equivalents can be found by typing " functional equivalent and country name".

_source.question: What is TIN
_source.answer:
Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) is a nine digit identification number used by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in the administration of tax laws in US. It is issued either by the Social Security Administration (SSA) or by the IRS. A Social Security number (SSN) is issued by the SSA whereas all other TINs are issued by the IRS. 

In the context of countries other than US, TIN is any tax identification number which has been issued in the respective countries for income tax purposes. The details of TIN are available on the OECD website. Please copy the link below and paste it on your browser to know TIN of OECD countries.
http://www.oecd.org/tax/automatic-exchange/crs-implementation-and-assistance/tax-identification-numbers/
variation: What is TIN
TIN
What is Tax Identification Number
Tax Identifciation Number

_source.question: Are pre-existing entity accounts exempt under CRS
_source.answer:
Non individual accounts existing as on December 31, 2015 with balance of USD 250,000 as on that date are exempt under CRS till the time they exceed USD 250,000 as of the last day of the calendar year.

Due diligence needs to be carried out for accounts which were more than USD 250,000 as on June 30, 2014.
variation: Are pre-existing entity accounts exempt under CRS

_source.question: What is the meaning of regularly traded on an established securities market
_source.answer:
The stock is “regularly traded” if there is a meaningful volume of trading with respect to the stock on an on-going basis with respect to each share class of the stock of the corporation.

“Each share class of the stock of the corporation” means one or more classes of the stock of the corporation that (i) were listed on one or more established securities markets during the prior calendar year and (ii), in aggregate, represent more than 50% of (a) the total combined voting power of all class of stock of such corporation entitled to vote and (b) the total value of the stock of such corporation.
variation: What is the meaning of regularly traded on an established securities market

_source.question: What is CRS
_source.answer:
CRS is known as Common Reporting Standards. It is an information standard for the automatic exchange of information (AEoI), developed in the context of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

The Common Reporting Standard (CRS) requires financial institutions in a jurisdiction to report to their tax administration the financial accounts held by non-resident individuals and entities or, certain entities controlled by non-resident individuals. Tax administrations are, in turn, expected to share the financial account information with other jurisdictions committed to the CRS through formalized arrangements.

The Government of India has also joined the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) on June 3, 2015 and financial institutions in India to comply with CRS.

_source.question: In case of an Entity if the assets could produce more than 50% passive income but do not actually produce any income in the period concerned will it be termed as Active or Passive NFE?
_source.answer: The test of whether an asset is held for the production of passive income does not require that passive income is actually produced in the period concerned. Instead, the asset must be of the type that produces or could produce passive income. For example, cash should be viewed as producing or being held for the production of passive income (interest) even if it does not actually produce such income.

_source.question: What is the impact on the Bank if the information collected is incorrect/wrong?
_source.answer:
Section 271FAA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 provides for levy of a penalty of Rs. 50,000 on Reporting Financial Institution (RFI) i.e. the bank, for furnishing inaccurate information in the statement of reportable account and where
(i) Inaccuracy is due to failure to comply with due diligence requirements or is deliberate on the part of the RFI
(ii) The RFI knows of the inaccuracy at the time of furnishing the statement of reportable account, but does not inform the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation
(iii) The RFI discovers the inaccuracy after the statement of reportable account is furnished and fails to inform and furnish the correct information to the Directorate of Intelligence and Criminal Investigation within 10 days.

_source.question: What if the customer is residing in US but having an account outside US
_source.answer:
Reporting Financial Institutions are required to obtain FATCA/CRs declaration from all account holders. If the US resident has approached the Bank for opening the account, then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained which should include the TIN/SSN of US. 

For existing customers having US indicia i.e. account opened prior to June 30, 2014, if the aggregate account balance or value of the US account holder exceeds USD 50000, then, FATCA/CRS declaration is to be provided by the customer. Moreover, if there is any change of circumstance in the account leading to an indicia outside India then, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained from that customer before processing the service request.
variation: What if the customer is residing in US but having an account outside US

_source.question: Difference between GIIN and TIN
_source.answer:
GIIN means a Global Intermediary Identification Number assigned to a PFFI or Registered Deemed Compliant FFI. A separate GIIN will be issued to the FI to identify each jurisdiction, including the FI's jurisdiction of residence, in which the FI maintains a branch that is not treated as a Limited Branch. GIIN is assigned to each financial institutions for purposes of identifying their registration with the IRS under FATCA.

A Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) is an identifying number used for tax purposes. TINs are different in each country.

_source.question: What is FATCA
_source.answer:
The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a United States federal law that requires United States persons, including US persons who live outside the United States, to report their financial accounts held outside of the United States, and requires foreign financial institutions to report to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) about their U.S. clients. 

Government of India (GOI) has signed a Model 1 Inter-Governmental Agreement (IGA) with US on July 9, 2015 which necessitates financial institutions in India to comply with FATCA.

_source.question: Can an Entity other than a corporation have “stock which is regularly traded on an established securities market"
_source.answer: The term “stock” is limited to shares in a corporation. Accordingly, only a corporation can qualify as an Active NFE on the basis of the fact that its stock is regularly traded on an established securities market.

_source.question: In determining whether an Entity meets the “50% gross income test” under the definition of Investment Entity, is it permissible to apply the three-year test on the final day of a non-calendar year accounting period, as foreseen for the “20% gross income test” for Custodial Institutions
_source.answer: The three-year test for determining whether an Entity meets the “50% gross income test” under the definition of Investment Entity may be applied on the final day of a non calendar year accounting period of the year preceding the year in which the determination is made.
