_source.question: Depository Institution
_source.answer:
Depository Institution means any entity that accepts deposits in the ordinary course of a banking or similar business.

Entities that fall within this definition include entities regulated in India as a bank, a  Loan Company, a credit society and non-banking financial companies.

A leasing, factoring or invoice discounting business or to an entity that solely lends to business enterprises using loans backed by inventory, accounts receivables, or machinery and equipment will not fall under the category of depository institution. 

Facilitating money transfers by instructing agents to transmit funds (without financing the transactions) is not be considered as the acceptance of a deposit and an entity will not be considered to be engaged in a banking or similar business or a depository institution because of this activity alone.
variation: Depository Institution
What is a depository institution

_source.question: What is Change of Circumstance
_source.answer:
Change of Circumstance includes any change that results in the addition of information relevant to a person’s status or otherwise conflicts with such person’s status. In addition, a change of circumstances includes any change or addition of information to the account holder’s account (including the addition, substitution, or other change of an account holder) or any change or addition of information to any account associated with such account (applying the account aggregation rules) if such change or addition of information affects the status of the account holder.

If there is a change in circumstance with respect to an account that causes the Reporting Financial institution to know or have reasons to know that the self-certification or any other documentation associated with an account is incorrect or unreliable, the Reporting FI must re-determine the status of the account in accordance with the applicable due diligence procedures immediately.
variation: What is Change of Circumstance

_source.question: Difference between TIN and functional equivalent
_source.answer:
A tax payer identification number (TIN) is a unique combination of letters or numbers, assigned by a country to an indivuidal or entity and used to identify the identify the individual or entity for the purpose of administering the tax laws of such country. 

Where a person is resident for tax purpose in more than one country or territory outside India, Bank shall maintain the TIN in respect of each such country or territory. 

Country specific TIN can be found by typing "TIN and country".

Many countries do not issue TIN to their taxpayers. However, such countries issue a high integrity number with equivalent level of identification. It is commonly known as functional equivalent. Examples are Social Security Number, National insurance number, Personal identifciation code, resident registration number, etc.

Country specific functional equivalents can be found by typing " functional equivalent and country"

_source.question: What is TIN
_source.answer:
Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) is a nine digit identification number used by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in the administration of tax laws in US. It is issued either by the Social Security Administration (SSA) or by the IRS. A Social Security number (SSN) is issued by the SSA whereas all other TINs are issued by the IRS. 

In the context of countries other than US, TIN is any tax identification number which has been issued in the respective countries for income tax purposes. The details of TIN are available on the OECD website. Please copy the link below and paste it on your browser to know TIN of OECD countries.
http://www.oecd.org/tax/automatic-exchange/crs-implementation-and-assistance/tax-identification-numbers/

TIN

_source.question: What is Active NFFE
_source.answer:
Active NFFE is a non-financial entity means any non-financial entity which meets any of the following criteria, namely:-
•	Less than 50 percent of the NFFE’s gross income for the preceding calendar year or other appropriate reporting period is passive income and less than 50 percent of the assets held by the NFFE during the preceding calendar year or other appropriate reporting period are assets that produce or are held for the production of passive income
•	The stock of NFFE or its affiliate is regularly traded on established securities market
•	The NFFE is a government (other than the U.S. government), a political subdivision of such government (which, for the avoidance of doubt, includes a state, province, county, or municipality), or a public body performing a function of such government or a political subdivision thereof, a government of a U.S. Territory, an international organization, a non-U.S. central bank of issue, or an entity wholly owned by one or more of the foregoing
•	The NFFE is organized in a U.S. Territory and all of the owners of the payee are bona fide residents of that U.S. Territory
•	The NFFE was not a FI in the past five years, and is in the process of liquidating its assets or is reorganizing with the intent to continue or recommence operations in a business other than that of a FI 
•	The NFFE meets all the requirements applicable to certain not-for-profit organizations
o	It is established and operated in its jurisdiction of residence exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, artistic, cultural, athletic, educational purposes or for promotion of social welfare
o	It is exempt from income tax in its jurisdiction of residence 
o	It has no shareholders or members who have a proprietary or beneficial interest in its income or assets
o	Applicable laws of the NFFE’s jurisdiction of residence  do not permit any income or assets of the NFFE to be distributed to, or applied for the benefit of, a private person or non-charitable Entity
o	Applicable laws of the NFFE’s jurisdiction of residence require that, upon liquidation or dissolution, all of its assets be distributed to a governmental entity or other non-profit organization

_source.question: In case of dual citizenship, what needs to be submitted by customer
_source.answer:
In case of dual citizenship,
•	If one of the country of citizenship is US, then TIN or SSN of US is to be mandatorily obtained from the customer. 
•	If country of citizenship is other than US and residence for tax purpose is the country of citizenship then, TIN has to be mandatorily obtained of that country.
•	If country of citizenship (other than US) and country of residence for tax purposes is different then, functional equivalent can be obtained of the country of citizenship and TIN to be mandatorily obtained for the country of tax residence.
variation: In case of dual citizenship, what needs to be submitted by customer

_source.question: What are the common errors in the FATCA / CRS information collected from customers by the bank?
_source.answer:
Some of the common errors are:
1.	Nationality or citizenship is US but TIN of US not available

2.	Nationality or citizenship is US but US TIN is less than or greater than 9 digits.
3.	Self-Certification for individuals is signed by the customer when he is not required to sign, i.e when there is any indicia outside India and customer is providing the TIN value of all such countries for which there is an indicia.
4.	Self-Certification for individuals is not signed by the customer when he is required to sign i.e. 
a.	When any of the indicia parameters is outside India and TIN or functional equivalent is not available since not a resident for tax purpose outside India or 
b.	Country of Birth is US and US person is mentioned as “No” in Part I of the FATCA / CRS declaration.
5.	TIN not provided by the customer when the customer is a resident for tax purposes in any country outside India.
6.	TIN provided is not as per the format prescribed by OECD for that country.
7.	Controlling person details including TIN, for entities which are Passive NFE, Specified US Persons or Owner documented FFI are not obtained.
variation: What are the common errors in the FATCA / CRS information collected from customers by the bank?

_source.question: I am not a citizen of US nor was I born there why are u seeking FATCA declaration from me?
_source.answer:
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015. 

Therefore, it is mandatory for Financial Institutions to obtain FATCA / CRS declaration even if there is no US indicia so that due diligence can be carried out and only reportable accounts can be reported to CBDT.

_source.question: What is the difference between country of residence and tax residence
_source.answer:
Usually, country of residence is where the customer is domiciled, i.e. where the customer lives with the intent to make it a fixed and permanent home. 

While an individual usually will be resident for tax purposes in a jurisdiction if, under the laws of that jurisdiction (including tax conventions), s/he pays or should be paying tax therein by reason of his domicile, residence or any other criterion of a similar nature, and not only from sources in that jurisdiction. Dual resident individuals may rely on the tiebreaker rules contained in tax conventions (if applicable) to solve cases of double residence for determining their residence for tax purposes. If the customer has any doubt, the customer should seek advice from a tax advisor. The Bank should not be advising in this regard.

_source.question: Why Bank is required to comply with FATCA/CRS
_source.answer:
The Common Reporting Standards (CRS) on Automatic Exchange Of Information (AEOI) requires the financial institutions of the “source” jurisdiction to collect and report information on yearly basis to the tax authorities of the source jurisdiction about account holders who are “resident” in other countries, The Government of India (GOI) has also joined the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) on 3rd June, 2015, for exchanging information.

GOI has signed a Model 1 Inter-Governmental Agreement (IGA) with US on July 9, 2015 which provides that the Indian FIs will provide the necessary information to Indian tax authorities, which will then be transmitted to USA automatically. 

FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. The details to be reported includes the Tax Identification Number (TIN) issued to the individual or entity in the country of its tax residence for CRS and US TIn for US persons. Hence, the Bank has finalised the FATCA/CRS declaration alongwith the TIN to comply with the Income Tax Rules, 1962. 

CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015.

Further following links are provided for your reference.

https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/tax-policy/treaties/Documents/FATCA-Agreement-India-7-9-2015.pdf
http://www.incometaxindia.gov.in/news/guidance-note-on-fatca-and-crs-may-2016.pdf

_source.question: If a person of Indian origin residing in US permanently moves back to India, is he a US person under FATCA
_source.answer:
US person is a person resident or citizen of US. If the person has aquired citizenship during his/her stay in US then, he/she will be termed as US person.
If the person has moved permanently to India without aquiring citizenship of US and is not a resident for tax purpose of US then, he/she will not be a US person.

However, FATCA/CRS declaration has to be mandatorily obtained at the time of account opening or change of circumstance.

_source.question: Financial Account
_source.answer:
Financial Account means an account (other than an excluded account) maintained by a financial institution, and includes- 
i.	a depository account, 
ii.	a custodial account,
iii.	in the case of an investment entity, any equity or debt interest in the financial institution,
iv.	in the case of a financial institution not described in sub-clause (iii), any equity or debt interest in the financial institution, if the class of interests was established with a purpose of avoiding reporting in accordance with rule 114G and, in case of a U.S. reportable account, if the value of the debt or equity interest is determined, directly or indirectly, primarily by reference to assets that give rise to U.S. source withholdable payments; and
v.	any cash value Insurance contract and any annuity contract issued or maintained by a financial institution, other than a noninvestment-linked, non-transferable immediate life annuity that is issued to an individual and monetizes a pension or disability benefit provided under an account that is an excluded account.

Financial account will not include any equity or debt interest in an entity that is an investment entity solely because it 
a.	renders investment advice to, and acts on behalf of, or 
b.	manages portfolios for, and acts on behalf of, a customer for the purpose of investing, managing, or administering financial assets deposited in the name of the customer with a financial institution that is not a non-participating financial institution other than such entity;
variation: Financial Account

_source.question: Closure of account under FATCA
_source.answer:
As per the IGA entered into between US and India, accounts opened between July 1, 2014 to August 31, 2015 were required to be closed. However, CBDT issued a press release to all financial institutions in India on April 11, 2017, that instead of closure of accounts, financial institutions shall not permit any customer induced transactions w.e.f May 1, 2017 in the accounts opened from July 1, 2014 to August 31, 2015 for which FATCA declaration could not be obtained. Hence, all financial institutions in India were required to mark a total freeze on the accounts.
However, there is no such requirement to close or freeze the account under CRS.

As india has entered into a Model 1 IGA with US government, the financial isntitutions in India will be guided by the rules/clarifications/guidance issued by CBDT from time to time.

_source.question: When is a trust that is a Financial Institution considered to be resident in a Participating Jurisdiction?
_source.answer: In general, a Financial Institution is resident in a Participating Jurisdiction if it is a resident for tax purposes in the jurisdiction. In the case of a trust that is a Financial Institution (irrespective of whether it is resident for tax purposes in a Participating Jurisdiction), the trust is considered to be a resident in a Participating Jurisdiction if one or more of its trustees are tax resident in such Participating Jurisdiction except if the trust reports all the information required to be reported to another Participating Jurisdiction because it is resident for tax purposes in such other Participating Jurisdiction.

_source.question: Does the Standard require a Reporting Financial Institution to retain a paper copy of the Documentary Evidence collected as part of its due diligence procedures?
_source.answer: No. A Reporting Financial Institution is not required to retain a paper copy of the Documentary Evidence, but may do so. A Reporting Financial institution may retain an original, certified copy, or photocopy of the Documentary Evidence or, instead, a notation of the type of documentation reviewed, the date the documentation was reviewed, and the document’s identification number (if any) (for example, a passport number).

_source.question: What should the Reporting FI do if it is unable to obtain a new and valid self-certification with respect to existing accounts
_source.answer: The Reporting FI is not required to close the account, but will have to report the Account Holder to the respective regulators based on the residence status provided in the original self-certification and any other jurisdiction(s) in which the Reporting FI has indications that the Account Holder is resident in. Reporting FIs are expected to continue to use reasonable efforts to obtain a valid self-certification from the Account Holder. Such efforts must be made at least once a year until (i) a new and valid self-certification or (ii) a reasonable explanation and documentation is obtained.

_source.question: What is to be done in cases where the customer’s Country of Birth is US & is a Tax resident of a country outside India.
_source.answer:
Following steps are to be followed:
•	Check with customer for TIN of US.
•	If the customer does not provide the TIN of US, then ask for relinquishment of citizenship certificate.
•	If the customer does not have such certificate, then ask for the reason for not having the relinquishment certificate.
•	Ask the customer to sign the self-certification section.of the FATCA/CRS declaration
•	Additionally, if the cutsomer iss resident for tax purpose in a country other than India and US, then, ask the customer to provide the TIN for his/her country of residence for tax purpose.

_source.question: What is a recalcitrant account holder?
_source.answer:
Generally, a recalcitrant account holder is any account holder that 
(1) fails to comply with reasonable requests for information necessary to determine if the account is a United States account; 
(2) fails to provide the name, address, and TIN of each “specified United States person” and each substantial United States owner of a United States owned foreign entity; or 
(3) fails to provide a waiver of any foreign law that would prevent a foreign financial institution from reporting information required under FATCA
variation: What is a recalcitrant account holder?

_source.question: I am US citizen with US passport, have a PAN and AADHHAR too, do I still need to give a FATCA certification. Why do I fill in the FATCA declaration?
_source.answer:
Yes, FATCA / CRS declaration is to be obtained for US citizens along with the SSN or TIN number of US.
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 form part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015.

_source.question: What is the difference between country of residence and tax residence
_source.answer:
Usually, country of residence is where the customer is domiciled, i.e. where the customer lives with the intent to make it a fixed and permanent home. 

While an individual usually will be resident for tax purposes in a jurisdiction if, under the laws of that jurisdiction (including tax conventions), s/he pays or should be paying tax therein by reason of his domicile, residence or any other criterion of a similar nature, and not only from sources in that jurisdiction. Dual resident individuals may rely on the tiebreaker rules contained in tax conventions (if applicable) to solve cases of double residence for determining their residence for tax purposes. If the customer has any doubt, the customer should seek advice from a tax advisor. The Bank should not be advising in this regard.

_source.question: Why Bank is required to comply with FATCA/CRS
_source.answer:
The Common Reporting Standards (CRS) on Automatic Exchange Of Information (AEOI) requires the financial institutions of the “source” jurisdiction to collect and report information on yearly basis to the tax authorities of the source jurisdiction about account holders who are “resident” in other countries, The Government of India (GOI) has also joined the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) on 3rd June, 2015, for exchanging information.

GOI has signed a Model 1 Inter-Governmental Agreement (IGA) with US on July 9, 2015 which provides that the Indian FIs will provide the necessary information to Indian tax authorities, which will then be transmitted to USA automatically. 

FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. The details to be reported includes the Tax Identification Number (TIN) issued to the individual or entity in the country of its tax residence for CRS and US TIn for US persons. Hence, the Bank has finalised the FATCA/CRS declaration alongwith the TIN to comply with the Income Tax Rules, 1962. 

CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015.

Further following links are provided for your reference.

https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/tax-policy/treaties/Documents/FATCA-Agreement-India-7-9-2015.pdf
http://www.incometaxindia.gov.in/news/guidance-note-on-fatca-and-crs-may-2016.pdf

_source.question: Are pre-existing entity accounts exempt under FATCA
_source.answer:
Non individual accounts existing as on June 30, 2014 with balance of USD 250,000 as on that date are exempt under FATCA till the time they exceed USD 250,000 as of the last day of the calendar year.

Due diligence needs to be carried out for accounts which were more than USD 250,000 as on June 30, 2014.

_source.question: Equity interest
_source.answer:
Equity interest in a financial institution, being-
(a)	a partnership firm means either a capital or profits interest in the partnership firm;
(b)	a trust means any interest held by any person treated as a settlor or beneficiary of all or a portion of the trust, or any other natural person exercising ultimate effective control over the trust. 

Debt or equity interests maintained by Depository Institutions, Custodial Institutions and Specified Insurance Companies would constitute Financial Accounts if:-
•	The value of such interests is determined primarily by reference to assets that give rise to US Source Withholdable Payments; and
•	The class of interests was established for the avoidance of reporting under the Agreement.
variation: Equity interest
What is Equity Interest

_source.question: Cash value insurance contract
_source.answer:
Cash value insurance contract means an insurance contract (other than an indemnity reinsurance contract between two insurance companies) that has a cash value and in case of a U.S. reportable account such value is greater than an amount equivalent to fifty thousand U.S. dollars.

A person will be treated as being a beneficiary of a trust if he has the right to receive directly or indirectly a mandatory distribution or may receive, directly or indirectly, a discretionary distribution from the trust.

A single premium life insurance contract which does not permit an amount to be paid on surrender or termination of the contract and which does not allow amounts to be borrowed under or with regard to the contract, shall not constitute a cash value insurance contract.

_source.question: What should a Reporting FI do with a new account for which the Account Holder had provided a valid self-certification at account opening, but subsequently the self-certification is found to fail the “reasonableness test”.
_source.answer:
Once the Reporting FI has obtained a valid self-certification, it must confirm the reasonableness of the self-certification, based on
•	the information obtained in connection with the opening of the account, 
•	any documentation obtained pursuant to AML/KYC procedures. 

A Reporting FI is considered to have confirmed the reasonableness of a self-certification if it does not know or have reason to know that the self-certification is incorrect or unreliable. Where the validation of the self-certification takes place after account opening and the self-certification fails the reasonableness test, the Reporting FI is expected to either obtain 
•	a new and valid self-certification or 
•	a reasonable explanation and documentation, as appropriate, supporting the reasonableness of the self-certification within the next 90 days.
variation: What should a Reporting FI do with a new account for which the Account Holder had provided a valid self-certification at account opening, but subsequently the self-certification is found to fail the “reasonableness test”.

_source.question: Applicability of FATCA / CRS
_source.answer:
FATCA and CRS read with section 285BA of the Income-tax Act, 1961 forms part of India’s local tax regime that provides for automatic exchange of financial account information. Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B provide basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts. This regime obliges financial institutions (FIs) to perform due diligence procedures and identify individuals that are reportable persons and certain entities in which any individual(s) that is/are reportable person(s) hold controlling interest. CBDT has finalized and released the rules 114F to 114H of the Income Tax Rule, 1962 on August 7, 2015. 

Therefore, it is mandatory for Financial Institutions to obtain FATCA / CRS declaration from all account holders irrespective of their residential status and any indicia outside India, so that due diligence can be carried out to identify the reportable accounts under FATCA/CRS.

_source.question: When an Indicia is found and the person denies that he/she is a citizen or resident of a country other than India, can we rely on the documentary evidence and self-certification that he/she is not a person of a country other than India or do we need some other form of self-certification?
_source.answer: In such cases we can rely on the self-certification that allows the account holder to positively acknowledge by signature or other means that the certification is correct provided he/she provides appropriate documentary evidence to confirm their status and the bank has no reason to believe that he/she is a citizen or resident of a country other than India.

_source.question: What are Reportable Accounts under CRS
_source.answer:
Accounts held by the following are reportable accounts under CRS
•	Person resident for tax purpose outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Passive NFE with controlling persons outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Entity resident for tax purpose outside the jurisdiction in which the account is opened
•	Other Reportable Person

_source.question: What is pre-existing high value individual accounts under FATCA
_source.answer:
Individual Accounts existing as on June 30, 2014 and having a balance more than USD 1,000,000 as on June 30, 2014 are high value accounts under FATCA. 
The threshold of USD 1,000,000 to be considered at UCIC level i.e. at customer level.

_source.question: Are rollovers considered as new accounts
_source.answer: The treatment of rollovers is the same under CRS and FATCA. Where some or all of the proceeds of a maturing fixed term product are rolled over, automatically or with the Account Holder’s interaction, into a new fixed term product, this shall not be deemed to be the creation of a New Account.

_source.question: Reporting due date for FATCA/CRS in India
_source.answer:
In India, FATCA and CRS reporting is to be done to Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) on an annual basis.

All information for the relevant reporting year is to be submitted to CBDT through Form 61B for every calendar year by 31st day of May of the year following the end of the reporting year. For example, a Reporting FI is required to submit information for Reporting Year 2017 to CBDT by 31st May 2018.

_source.question: What is FATCA
_source.answer:
The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a United States federal law that requires United States persons, including US persons who live outside the United States, to report their financial accounts held outside of the United States, and requires foreign financial institutions to report to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) about their U.S. clients. 

Government of India (GOI) has signed a Model 1 Inter-Governmental Agreement (IGA) with US on July 9, 2015 which necessitates financial institutions in India to comply with FATCA.

_source.question: What are the common errors in the FATCA / CRS information collected from customers by the bank?
_source.answer:
Some of the common errors are:
1.	Nationality or citizenship is US but TIN of US not available

2.	Nationality or citizenship is US but US TIN is less than or greater than 9 digits.
3.	Self-Certification for individuals is signed by the customer when he is not required to sign, i.e when there is any indicia outside India and customer is providing the TIN value of all such countries for which there is an indicia.
4.	Self-Certification for individuals is not signed by the customer when he is required to sign i.e. 
a.	When any of the indicia parameters is outside India and TIN or functional equivalent is not available since not a resident for tax purpose outside India or 
b.	Country of Birth is US and US person is mentioned as “No” in Part I of the FATCA / CRS declaration.
5.	TIN not provided by the customer when the customer is a resident for tax purposes in any country outside India.
6.	TIN provided is not as per the format prescribed by OECD for that country.
7.	Controlling person details including TIN, for entities which are Passive NFE, Specified US Persons or Owner documented FFI are not obtained.
variation: What are the common errors in the FATCA / CRS information collected from customers by the bank?

_source.question: What are the documents to be collected if the customer is tax resident in multiple overseas jurisdiction / countries?

TIN number is required for all the countries in which the customer is a tax resident. No documentary proof is required.
However. If TIN provided by the customer is not matching with the TIN, syntax provided by OECD. Obtain the tax return copy or any other relevant document which states the Tax number for the customer in the country of his/her tax residence.

_source.question: What is the role of CBDT in FATCA/CRS?
_source.answer:
In view of India’s commitment to implement the CRS on Automatic Exchange of Information (AEOI) with other countries and also the Intergovernmental Agreement (IGA) with USA, necessary legislative changes have been made.  Income-tax Rules, 1962 were amended vide Notification No. 62 of 2015 dated 7th August, 2015 by inserting Rules 114F to 114H and Form 61B to provide a legal basis for the Reporting Financial Institutions (RFIs) for maintaining and reporting information about the Reportable Accounts.
Reporting Financial Institutions are required to report details of Reportable accounts to Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT). CBDT in turn shares the Reportable data with respective jurisdictions. CBDT issues guidance and clarifications from time to time on various aspects of FATCA/CRS implementation and compliance. CBDT can levy penalty for non-compliance of the FATCA/CRS rules by financial institutions in India.

_source.question: Local FFI
_source.answer:
An FFI is a local FFi if it meets the following requirements:
1.	The FFI is licensed and regulated as a financial institution under the laws of its country of incorporation or organization (which must be a FATFcompliant jurisdiction at the time the FFI registers for deemed-compliant status).
2.	The FFI does not have a fixed place of business outside its country of incorporation or organization. For this purpose, a fixed place of business does not include a location that is not advertised to the public and from which the FFI performs solely administrative support functions.
3.	The FFI does not solicit customers or account holders outside its country of incorporation or organization.
4.	The FFI is required under the laws of its country of incorporation or organization to identify resident account holders for purposes of either information reporting or withholding of tax with respect to accounts held by residents or is required to identify resident accounts for purposes of satisfying such country’s AML due diligence requirements.
5.	At least 98 percent of the accounts by value maintained by the FFI as of the last day of the preceding calendar year are held by residents (including residents that are entities) of the country in which the FFI is incorporated or organized.
6.	Policies and procedures must provide that if any account of specified US person is discovered, the FFI will close such account, transfer such account to a participating FFI, reporting Model 1 FFI, or U.S. financial institution, or withhold and report on such account as would be required under if the FFI were a participating FFI.

_source.question: How is the residency of a fiscally transparent Financial Institution (other than a trust) to be determined
_source.answer:
Where a Financial Institution (other than a trust) is fiscally transparent, it is a Participating Jurisdiction Financial Institution if: 
a) it is incorporated under the laws of the Participating Jurisdiction; 
b) it has its place of management in the Participating Jurisdiction; or 
c) it is subject to financial supervision in the Participating Jurisdiction.

_source.question: Is the Bank required to collect any documentary proof other than FATCA/CRS declaration?
_source.answer:
There is no requirement to obtain any documentary proof other than FATCA/CRS declaration. It is the responsibility of the customer to provide correct and accurate details. However, the Bank has to exercise due diligence at the time of obtaining the FATCA/CRS declaration. If there is any reason for the branch/RM/operations to believe that the data provided is incorrect, then, necessary documents should be obtained to substantiate the data provided in the FATCA/CRS declaration. 
Examples: 
1. If TIN provided by the customer is not matching with the TIN, syntax provided by OECD. Obtain the tax return copy or any other relevant document which states the Tax number for the customer in the country of his/her tax residence.
2. Permanent address on AOF is of outside India but in declaration form the customer says ‘No’ to any relation outside of India then revised FATCA/CRS declaration or appropriate justification/reasoning to be provided.
3. If the customer is born in US and states that he/she is not a US person then relinquishment of citizenship certificate to be obtained as documentary proof from the customer.

_source.question: What are the types of Withholding certificates
_source.answer:

•	W8BEN (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding)(Individuals)
•	W8BENE (Certificate of Foreign Status of US Tax Withholding) (Entities)
•	W8ECI (Certificate of Foreign Person's Claim That Income Is Effectively Connected With the Conduct of a Trade or Business in the United States)
•	W8EXP (Certificate of Foreign Government or Other Foreign Organization for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
•	W8IMY (Certificate of Foreign Intermediary, Foreign Flow-Through Entity, or Certain U.S. Branches for United States Tax Withholding and Reporting)
•	W9 (Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification)

_source.question: What is the definition of a U.S. source payment
_source.answer:
•	U.S. source income is income that arises from sources within the U.S. The source of income is determined based on the type of income. 
•	The source of compensation income is where the services giving rise to the income were performed.
•	The source of certain income, such as dividends and interest, is based on residence of the payer.
•	The source of income from property is based on where the property is used.
variation: What is the definition of a U.S. source payment
US Source payment
U.S. source payment

_source.question: What is the meaning of regularly traded on an established securities market
_source.answer:
The stock is “regularly traded” if there is a meaningful volume of trading with respect to the stock on an on-going basis with respect to each share class of the stock of the corporation.

“Each share class of the stock of the corporation” means one or more classes of the stock of the corporation that (i) were listed on one or more established securities markets during the prior calendar year and (ii), in aggregate, represent more than 50% of (a) the total combined voting power of all class of stock of such corporation entitled to vote and (b) the total value of the stock of such corporation.
variation: What is the meaning of regularly traded on an established securities market
what is regularly traded stock

_source.question: Local FFI
_source.answer:
An FFI is a local FFi if it meets the following requirements:
1.	The FFI is licensed and regulated as a financial institution under the laws of its country of incorporation or organization (which must be a FATFcompliant jurisdiction at the time the FFI registers for deemed-compliant status).
2.	The FFI does not have a fixed place of business outside its country of incorporation or organization. For this purpose, a fixed place of business does not include a location that is not advertised to the public and from which the FFI performs solely administrative support functions.
3.	The FFI does not solicit customers or account holders outside its country of incorporation or organization.
4.	The FFI is required under the laws of its country of incorporation or organization to identify resident account holders for purposes of either information reporting or withholding of tax with respect to accounts held by residents or is required to identify resident accounts for purposes of satisfying such country’s AML due diligence requirements.
5.	At least 98 percent of the accounts by value maintained by the FFI as of the last day of the preceding calendar year are held by residents (including residents that are entities) of the country in which the FFI is incorporated or organized.
6.	Policies and procedures must provide that if any account of specified US person is discovered, the FFI will close such account, transfer such account to a participating FFI, reporting Model 1 FFI, or U.S. financial institution, or withhold and report on such account as would be required under if the FFI were a participating FFI.
variation: Local FFI

_source.question: Investment Entity
_source.answer:
Investment entity means any entity,-
(A) that primarily conducts as a business one or more of the following activities or operations for or on behalf of a customer, namely:-
(i)	trading in money market instruments (cheques, bills, certificates of deposit, derivatives, etc.); foreign exchange; exchange, interest rate and index instruments; transferable securities; or commodity futures trading; or
(ii) 	individual and collective portfolio management; or
(iii)	otherwise investing, administering, or managing financial Assets or money on behalf of other persons; or

(B) the gross income of which is primarily attributable to investing, reinvesting, or trading in financial assets, if the entity is managed by another entity that is a depository institution, a custodial institution, a specified insurance company, or an investment entity described in sub-clause (A) of this clause.

An entity is treated as primarily conducting as a business one or more of the activities described in clause (A) above, or an entity’s gross income is primarily attributable to investing, reinvesting, or trading in financial assets as mentioned in clause (B), if the entity’s gross income attributable to the relevant activities equals or exceeds 50 percent of the entity’s gross income during the shorter of the three-year period ending on 31 March of the year preceding the year in which the determination is made or the period during which the entity has been in existence.
variation: Investment Entity
What is an investment entity

_source.question: Equity interest
_source.answer:
Equity interest in a financial institution, being-
(a)	a partnership firm means either a capital or profits interest in the partnership firm;
(b)	a trust means any interest held by any person treated as a settlor or beneficiary of all or a portion of the trust, or any other natural person exercising ultimate effective control over the trust. 

Debt or equity interests maintained by Depository Institutions, Custodial Institutions and Specified Insurance Companies would constitute Financial Accounts if:-
•	The value of such interests is determined primarily by reference to assets that give rise to US Source Withholdable Payments; and
•	The class of interests was established for the avoidance of reporting under the Agreement.

_source.question: Cash value insurance contract
_source.answer:
Cash value insurance contract means an insurance contract (other than an indemnity reinsurance contract between two insurance companies) that has a cash value and in case of a U.S. reportable account such value is greater than an amount equivalent to fifty thousand U.S. dollars.

A person will be treated as being a beneficiary of a trust if he has the right to receive directly or indirectly a mandatory distribution or may receive, directly or indirectly, a discretionary distribution from the trust.

A single premium life insurance contract which does not permit an amount to be paid on surrender or termination of the contract and which does not allow amounts to be borrowed under or with regard to the contract, shall not constitute a cash value insurance contract.

_source.question: What is CRS
_source.answer:
CRS is known as Common Reporting Standards. It is an information standard for the automatic exchange of information (AEoI), developed in the context of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

The Common Reporting Standard (CRS) requires financial institutions in a jurisdiction to report to their tax administration the financial accounts held by non-resident individuals and entities or, certain entities controlled by non-resident individuals. Tax administrations are, in turn, expected to share the financial account information with other jurisdictions committed to the CRS through formalized arrangements.

The Government of India has also joined the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) on June 3, 2015 and financial institutions in India to comply with CRS.

_source.question: How is the residency of a fiscally transparent Financial Institution (other than a trust) to be determined
_source.answer:
Where a Financial Institution (other than a trust) is fiscally transparent, it is a Participating Jurisdiction Financial Institution if: 
a) it is incorporated under the laws of the Participating Jurisdiction; 
b) it has its place of management in the Participating Jurisdiction; or 
c) it is subject to financial supervision in the Participating Jurisdiction.

_source.question: In case of an Entity if the assets could produce more than 50% passive income but do not actually produce any income in the period concerned will it be termed as Active or Passive NFE?
_source.answer: The test of whether an asset is held for the production of passive income does not require that passive income is actually produced in the period concerned. Instead, the asset must be of the type that produces or could produce passive income. For example, cash should be viewed as producing or being held for the production of passive income (interest) even if it does not actually produce such income.

conv_ans.answer:
TIN in UK is Unique Taxpayer reference(UTR) or National Insurance Number. UTR is of 10 numerals. NINO is of 9 characters. 
National Insurance Number (NINO) is issued to young people living in UK when they approach the age of 16.
NINO  consists of two letters, six numbers and a suffix letter A, B, C or D. TINs are not issued to all UK resident taxpayers or all nationals. This includes those under 16 years of age, those who do not have a right to work in the UK as well as those with no UK tax or National Insurance Contributions Liability.
UTR can be found on front page of Tax Return. NINO can be found on Coding Notices by HM Revenue & Customs, National Insurance Card, Letters issued by Dept. of Work & Pensions(DWP), employee's pay slip.

_source.question: Difference between GIIN and LEI
_source.answer:
A Gloabl intermediary Identification Number (GIIN) is a 19-digit alphanumeric identification number. For FATCA reporting Financial Institutions (FIs) will use the GIIN to identify themselves to withholding agents and tax administrations. Once an FI’s FATCA registration is submitted and approved only then is a GIIN issued and only to FIs that are not Limited FFIs, Limited Branches, or U.S. branches of an FFI but to a Participating Foreign Financial Institution (PFFI) or a Registered Deemed-Compliant FFI (RDCFFI).

Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) is a 20-digit alphanumeric code used to identify legal entities. 

The LEI is at a legal entity level and the GIIN is at a lower branch level, a one-to-many relation. A separate GIIN will be issued to a FI to identify each jurisdiction, including the FI’s jurisdiction of residence, in which the FI maintains a branch.

_source.question: What is the main obligation for financial institutions under FATCA and CRS
_source.answer:
Financial institutions must perform extended due diligence during the customer onboarding and account opening process to identify US persons (individuals and entities). This will be achieved through the completion of the FATCA/CRS declaration form that must be signed by all new customers as well as existing customers opening
additional accounts.

conv_ans.answer:
Excluded/exempt accounts under FATCA/CRS are specified under Explanation to Rule 114F(1) of the Income Tax Rules, 1962
i.	Retirement or pension accounts Explanation (h)(i) to Rule 114F(1) 
ii.	Non-retirement tax-favored accounts Explanation (h)(ii) to Rule 114F(1). 
iii.	Account established under the Senior Citizens Savings Scheme Rules Explanation (h) (iii) to Rule 114F(1). 
iv.	Term Life Insurance contracts satisfying certain conditions Explanation (h)(iv) to Rule 114F(1) 
v.	Accounts held by Estates Explanation (h)(v) to Rule 114F(1). 
vi.	Escrow Accounts established in connection with court judgments; a sale, exchange, or lease of real or personal property; an obligation of a financial institution servicing a loan secured by real property to set aside a portion of a payment solely to facilitate the payment of taxes or insurance related to the real property at a later time; an obligation of a financial institution solely to facilitate the payment of taxes at a later time; Explanation (h)(vi) to Rule 114F(1). 
vii.	Depository accounts (other than US reportable accounts) due to non-returned overpayments in case of credit card and other accounts and satisfying certain conditions Explanation (h)(vii) to Rule 114F(1).

conv_ans.question: Company
conv_ans.answer:
Natural person who
a. has a controlling ownership interest (>25%) or
b. who exercises control through right to appoint majority of the directors or to control the management or policy decisions including by virtue of their shareholding or management rights or shareholders agreements or voting agreements.
If there is no natural person holding more than 25% in the company then senior managing officials or any person who exercises control over the company shall be the controlling person.
variation: Company

conv_ans.question: Partnership Firm
conv_ans.answer: Natural person who has ownership of/entitlement to more than fifteen per cent (15 %) of capital or profits of the partnership.
variation: Partnership Firm

conv_ans.question: Unincorporated Association or Body of Individuals or Society
conv_ans.answer:
Natural person who has ownership of or entitlement to more than fifteen per cent (15 %) of the property or capital or profits of such association or body of individuals.
If there is no natural person holding more than 15% then any person who exercises control over the association or body of individuals or society shall be the controlling person.
variation: Unincorporated Association or Body of Individuals or Society
Unincorporated Association or Body of Individuals

conv_ans.question: Trust

_source.question: Is FATCA applicable to directors who are not beneficial owners or authorised signatory of the entity
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be provided by the entity/non individual account holder. If the entity or the controlling person/beneficial owner is a US person or resident for atx purpose outside India then, controlling person details are required to be provided in the FATCA self-certifciation for non individuals. 

Controlling person is determined by the percentage of holding in the company. If there is no natural person holding more than 25% ownership in the company, then details of senior managing officials who exercise control over the company are required to be obtained in Section 4 of FATCA/CRS self-certification for non individuals.

However, individual FATCA/CRS declaration is not required from directors or authorised signatories.

_source.question: Is FATCA declaration required to be obtained at the time of re-kyc
_source.answer:
FATCA/CRS declaration has to be obtained at the time of on-boarding of the customer i.e. account opening and for every change in circumstance.

Currently, for ICICI Bank india, we have not mandated it as a part of re-kyc.

The change in circumstance includes:
1.Change in address to foreign address
2. Update of mobile number to foreign number
3. Addition of signatories in Current account
4. Addition of Power of Attorney (POA)
5. Addition of account holder in Savings account
6. Change in name / title of current account
7. Change in status from Minor to Major if any of the indicia parameter (address, telephone no. citizenship, birth, standing instruction for remittance or power of attorney holder, hold mail or in care of address) is outside India.
8. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
9. Change in citizenship – NRI to RI

For NRI cutsomers, change in circumstances can be under following scenarios:
1. Change in address - country change (Foreign)
2. Updation of mobile number (foreign number)
3. Addition of account holder in Savings account ( Joint Holder addition )
4. Addition of account holder in Savings account - Mandate holder
5. Change in citizenship – RI to NRI
6. Change in status from Minor to Major
7. Account Activation

For detailed process, kindly refer e-circular no. 14749

conv_ans.question: Individual
conv_ans.answer:
TIN for Individuals in Chile is National Identity No (RUN). It is of 9 alpha numeric characters.
At the end is the check digit which is a no. between 0 to 9 or a letter K.
It can be found on National Identity Card, Driver’s license, Deeds, Contracts, Invoices, Import and export documents.
